segments.text: Now is the time for all good men to come to the aid of their country.
Now is the time for all good men to come to the aid of their country.
Now is the time.
Now is the time for all good men to come to the aid of their country.
Dr. Mobley, it's nice to be here with you this morning.
You would tell us, please, sir, who you are and where you came from originally.
Well, indeed, William Hodges Mobley, and I was
Born in Akron, Ohio in November the 15th, 1941.
And I grew up in the Akron area.
Went to public schools there.
Went off to a small liberal arts school in Ohio called Denison University.
And I graduated there in 1963.
degree in psychology and a minor in economics.
Thoroughly enjoyed that small liberal arts school experience.
And as with many of those small schools, one of their objectives is to encourage as many as possible to go on to graduate school or professional school.
And so I had that instilled early on.
But I took a circuitous route.
I went to work first.
And with a psychology major, they're limited.
entry-level opportunities for back in those times.
I went to work in human resources.
I really was lucky.
A company called PPG Industries used to be called Pittsburgh Plate Glass.
They got hired there in their personnel employee relations department.
My first major job after a six-month or so orientation was to
go on the college recruiting circuits.
So I spent two years out visiting universities all over this country doing recruiting and thoroughly enjoyed that.
The travel were out in a hurry, but the ability to see a lot of universities... Did you get down to this part of the world?
I did, indeed, in several ways.
We did college recruiting during the year, but during that time, PPG was in an expansion mode and building plants all over the country, including here in Texas.
The...
A plant was built in Wichita Falls at the time.
It was one of the largest glass plants in the world.
It was a new location.
We had Houston Chemical here outside of Beaumont.
We had a plant in Corpus Christi, one across the border in Lake Charles, Louisiana.
A lot of distribution centers.
So there was a lot of activity here in Texas.
What years were those?
This would have been 64 through 67.
I worked PPG.
I had some other assignments.
I was in Pittsburgh in employee relations and labor relations and others.
And then they sent me down to their largest GLAST operation, which was in Cumberland, Maryland, to be director of training and development.
And I enjoyed that assignment.
And by that time, we had a daughter, and we're thinking, well, about the next year, we'll go back to graduate school.
And that had been my plan all along, and then to do it in organizational psychology.
Well, during early in my assignment in Cumberland, Maryland, I had an opportunity to meet the people at the University of Maryland on a project we were doing with them.
So I got to know them.
But I was still thinking in my field, some of the stronger organizational psychology programs are really in the Big Ten, Illinois and Ohio State and Minnesota.
So I'd been thinking there long.
But I'd gotten to know the people at Maryland.
And they called me.
It was around Easter.
Because when we went over, the cherry blossoms were already blooming.
I remember that.
And I took our little youngster.
And they called.
And one of the faculty members I'd gotten to know had just gotten a new NIH grant.
And he said, I've got a fellowship.
You'll come over.
So we chucked over there for a weekend and took a look at it and decided, let's do it.
Which we did.
And I wouldn't look back for a minute.
I got it.
It was a great experience, superb education at the University of Maryland.
For four years we lived in graduate student housing at the University of Maryland.
I took a leave from PPG and they continued to treat me very well.
They gave me consulting assignments and they had a stock plan vested.
That kept vesting each year we were in school, and that helped us live with some creature comfort while in graduate school.
So we had a good experience there and had our second daughter in Washington while we lived there.
So it was a good experience.
Then I went back to PPG for two years, started their human resource and employee relations research function.
They never had that.
So you're talking about roughly 1971?
That's right, 1971 to 1973.
I went back to PPG.
And you have a Ph.D. now in industrial organization psychology.
And by that time, kind of the behavioral things were really beginning to take hold in business.
There's still a lot of faddishness,
I think the awakening that the human resource is the comparative advantage and we really need to find more effective ways to deal with and manage and lead the human resource.
So we set up a pretty exciting
employee relations research program by academic standards very applied, obviously.
We were looking at things like job enrichment, job design, team building, leadership, compensation, employee turnover.
So interesting practical problems.
Some of it we farmed out to university people.
Some we put in internal teams together.
Exciting times.
During that time, I had a chance to teach at Carnegie Mellon and kind of got excited about teaching.
And I told my colleagues at PPG that at some point I was probably going to have to try that and they understood that.
I think would have preferred that I stayed in Pittsburgh.
Indeed, I had a job offer from Carnegie Mellon when I decided to go.
But about that time, we went down and looked at the University of South Carolina, which was making a major commitment to build their business school, including their international dimension.
And by this time, I'd also kind of become
focused on the importance of international issues.
PPG was becoming a major international participant and was learning some of the lessons the hard way.
They had a few missteps abroad and basically were lack of understanding of the cultures in which they were going to operate.
So anyway, that got me intrigued about that.
Well, South Carolina was very intriguing.
Kind of a new start, a very aggressive dean, a lot of support.
So I joined the faculty there in 73.
And one of the things we did was to start a center for management and organizational research.
And we got some office and naval research funding.
And so we had some really good experience there.
We were well-funded, a good research program, began to attract some good students.
Were you teaching also?
Teaching, you bet, you bet, in the organizational behavior area.
I think we had O&R funding the whole time I was there.
So we were there seven years, 73 to 80.
The international program was still doing very well.
Absolutely.
And I was just on the fringes of it.
A fellow named Randy Foulkes was really the guru of it, still there.
Very well conceived.
A lot of time spent on thinking about what it ought to be.
It was a very integrated program.
It wasn't just a collection of courses.
You took things, area study, for example, you'd look at the
the culture, the economy, marketing strategies, all in kind of a module.
So it was integrated and had a required language and a required internship requirement.
When did Carlson leave?
Carlson's daughter is over there right now.
Yes.
Just got to Paris, I think, for her internship.
And they've been placing those students well, and I think in part because it's good quality content, but that internship does indeed set them aside, and they've had some hands-on experience.
I've encountered their graduates just all over the place.
The State Department seems to like them, Citicorp, some of the multinational firms.
That's a good program, and I think by all accounts is clearly one of the top three international business programs now, which is good.
And South Carolina has some strengths overall.
They've kind of put it together.
Not the university this is, but they have focused on some areas and done it very well, and that's one of them.
So we stayed there 73 through 80 and thoroughly enjoyed South Carolina as a state and a place to live and a university and was growing.
In 78, 79, we took Fulbright.
Did you ever run into the librarian there, Ken Toombs?
Yeah, yeah.
Ken and I were real good friends.
Is that right?
Yeah, he was from the University of Southwestern Louisiana.
How about that?
Yeah, I hadn't thought of that name in a good while.
Excuse me.
In 78, 79 we took a leave and went on a Fulbright to Taiwan.
That was a good year.
I'd been promoted, and then the children were kind of young teenagers and pre-teen.
So we thought if we were going to do it, that would be the time to do it.
As you know, Fulbrights don't pay particularly well.
But that particular year, for organizational psychology, I think there were only two.
One was Taiwan, the other was Kiev.
So our assessment was, well, it would probably be easier to get to Russia over the years than it was going to be to get to the Orient.
So it turned out that may have been reversed.
But we wouldn't change it.
We had a great year, probably the best year we've ever had as a family.
The girls were a little reluctant to go.
And after flying, I don't know, 24 hours or whatever it took,
to get there.
We arrived and were taken to the wrong housing and just deposited by two young students who didn't have any better information than we had.
So we felt very, very deposited in a very strange culture.
So we flagged down a taxi and through pointing got to a hotel and slept for a day or two and found our way to the
to the embassy and everything got straightened out.
And from that point on, it was just a superb experience, culturally, educationally.
The children, I think, learned to adapt very quickly.
That's a good experience.
Oh, absolutely.
And the time they left, they were just so confident.
You could see their growth over that time.
Just very comfortable.
I had picked up enough language to cope.
So great year.
Anyway, we came back to South Carolina then for a year.
And at that point, I think I decided to sample some administrative kind of tracks.
And one of the things available then was the department head in management at Texas A&M.
And I'd known Don Helrigel for a long time.
And it was clear nationally that this business school was coming to life in Texas.
Exciting, oil was rising.
So we came down, had a great visit, very impressed.
Bill Mews was dean at the time and he had some excitement and vision.
We met a lot of faculty that were excited about what was happening and could happen here at A&M.
Through the PPG years,
spent enough time down here, and we recruited a lot of people from A&M.
We had some familiarity.
I wouldn't say we really knew the university or its culture, but enough feel.
But very impressed with what the business school hoped to do.
So we decided to come here and did in the summer of 1980, and have been here since.
No, and your progression quickly through the College of Business and what has happened to the College of Business maybe in those years.
Well, as you know, the College of Business is one of the newer colleges in this university.
It wasn't until, I guess, the mid-60s.

when a lot of the change was occurring at A&M, that the business school was split off from, originally had been over in ag, and I guess really started as cotton accounting, if I may have read that in your book.
Something like that.
But then what I guess was a kind of a combination unit that was an arts and science unit, and then when John Peterson, John Pearson was dean, yeah, or the first dean,
Things started to, I think, form.
It really exploded.
I guess that's about the only explanation.
Yep.
And I think I spent some time several years ago trying to, and before John died, I spent some time with him trying to reconstruct the dynamics of that era.
Dick Winerdi and John Calhoun and some others have shared with me their perceptions.
I think a couple.
One, giving it a separate identity.
Two, I think that John Pearson and some of the others that were kind of guiding it made some very important early hires and early decisions.
You know, they've got George Rice here.
George, with a doctorate from Stanford, just kind of set a tone.
Absolutely.
He said, you know, one A&M serious, and then they can hire a Stanford PhD.
George's family was from here in the Valley, so I guess there were other variables.
In my own mind, Don Hellriegel...
probably Bob Strouser in accounting, Don Fraser and Pete Rose over in finance.
Some of those earlier hires, it hadn't been that long ago, and these are still relatively young people.
But those were people that were about the business of making a national reputation for themselves.
knew how to engage in the scholarly activity, were committed to building an institution, committed to staying here, and they just planted the seeds.
And I've skipped, I shouldn't even start down names.
Tom Leland was a name during that transition period

apparently very well known and respected in the accounting profession in Texas, and helped get the accounting program started, and that was really the base, I think, upon which the others, and today, our accounting program is well regarded.
I think the college had some strong people who had national impact,
and who were committed to building an institution here.
Some very good moves were made, the notion of getting into business computing science, the application side, very early.
The decision to
This is more recent, to limit enrollment and not let it get totally out of control.
Who was dean when you came?
I was trying to think.
When I came, it was Bill Mews.
Yeah, Bill, sure.
In fact, yeah, I followed Bill.
Let's see, there have been very few deans.
John Pearson, Clint Phillips, been acting a couple of times.
Acting, that's right, for short term, yeah.
Bill Mews may have been the next.
He probably was, yeah.
And then I think I followed Bill.
When did you become dean?
Oh, me, let's see.
I'll get off your feet, but that's all right.
Yeah, I'm not sure.
Bill left and went to Ohio?
Where'd he go?
He went to the University of Akron.
Akron, University of Akron, yeah, sure.
Well, he went from dean, he went to be deputy chancellor first, or vice chancellor for a year or two, when Art Hanson was here.
And then went from there to Akron, and now is president of Auburn.
Good person.
I think the business school, good curriculum, good faculty,
I think it has kept its eye on quality, has earned the support of the business community.
My guess is it's really sort of the third leg now of the university in the sense of the old ag engineering.
I think it's really come on.
Benton Coconut, I think it's just been.
A superb dean.
Just excellent.
And what's happened over there in the last several years, I think the national reputation has finally taken hold.
Good chairs and good scholarships.
You bet.
Those things really add up.
Absolutely.
Absolutely.
As Dean, what were any special problems, encounters you had?
Well, I think one, the rapid enrollment growth was a constant challenge.
We were always chasing space and faculty positions, so getting enrollment growth under control was important.
Two, the global economy was clearly upon us, so our need to do more, and I think we did make some progress in getting more of an international perspective into the curriculum.
emphasizing getting a study abroad program.
Third, resources clearly weren't keeping up as we moved further into the 80s, so the need to get organized for private support, and I think that effort got underway.
And then the constant need to be recruiting good faculty and retaining them.
We were still growing and still had faculty positions, so a lot of time and resources were being spent on recruitment and retention.
And I think we have managed to attract some very good people.
While you were dean, was Frank Vandiver president?
Yes, he was.
That's right.
When I got here,

In fact, I vividly remember that first fall, very early, the former students had a welcoming reception for department heads, and something was over at the Ramada, and Frank Hubert walked in and made an announcement.
He was the new something, and I guess that was Jarvis Miller and Frank, and that would have been, I guess, fall of 1980.
as department head, and I had no idea what the significance of all this was until a number of months later.
But that indeed was what was going on.
Yeah, Frank was the...
So you were dean until when?
Let's see.
Until 86, I guess.
Yeah, because I think I spent two years in the chancellor's office then.
One or two.
I think it was 86.
And then went over to the, yeah, I was there two years.
I'd been 86 to 88 in the chancellor's office.
And when Perry Atkinson became chancellor,
By that time, Bill Mews had gone on to Akron.
So Perry was, I think, looking for someone to kind of oversee the academic side of things and invited me to join him.
And with some trepidation, I guess.
I wasn't sure about that.
Probably rightfully so, in my guess.
But I decided to take a look at that.
And again, it worked out very well.
I knew Perry, but not well.
And just found him, to me, the salt of the earth.
Just solid, honest, straightforward, hardworking guy.
And I learned a lot about politics and about how you don't have to make a lot of noise to get things done.
And Perry, I learned a heck of a lot from him.
And I'm grateful for that opportunity.
But it also broadened my horizons about a lot of the broader state and educational issues that were going on.
And the South Texas discussions had started by then.
So I was involved in some of that early discussion.
clearly see more clearly some of the tensions between the agencies and the university and the so-called flagship university and the smaller campuses in the system.
And it also, the resource constraints had begun to get serious in 85 forward.
And I got my first real dose of legislative interaction while over there.
You spent much time in Austin?
Yes.
You were associate chancellor?
I was, what do they call it?
First year was deputy chancellor for academic affairs, I think.
And then they changed the title to executive deputy chancellors.
Perry spent an awful lot of time in Washington, appropriately, on federal issues.
Second, he got an appointment to the National Science Board.
So he had some important reasons to be gone, and I think what he wanted was just someone to be clearly delegated to.
So I ended up with that title in 87, 88, I guess.
But a good bit of time in Austin or working legislator, meeting with legislators.
Did you meet with the regents also?
Yeah, yeah.
And that was one of the opportunities to interact with the regents.
I think Perry took that responsibility seriously and personally, I think.
And I think he said on many occasions that one group you just got to spend the time communicating with is Chancellor.
And he said he'd seen enough here and elsewhere who neglected that link.
And so I think he worked hard on staying in touch and communicating and visiting and going around visiting
with regents and trying to keep them informed and advised.
By this time, was there a pretty good accord or more or less tension between the main university, let's say, and the system?
I think that tension's always there and will always be there.
And as I've matured and talked with other
presidents and chancellors around the country, I think any system where there's a large flagship or dominant flagship, that tension is there in some form and at some level.
I think it works relatively better or more poorly
depending on how well the people in, I think, the two key roles communicate.
And they can make it work or they can make it not work.
And I think it's working here and it will continue to work here because people want to make it work.
It's kind of interesting in my mind that, you know, Vandiver was named, what, President of Texas A&M University and of the system, and then they went back to the chancellorship.
No, I didn't know that.
Yes.
I didn't know that.
I think given the size and complexity of the system and just the insatiable demands on time for the president of A&M, it would be inhuman and inappropriate.
It was.
That happened to a number of our former presidents and chancellors.
I've heard that said, and I can understand that.
It's just too much.
And the roles are different as long as they're clearly defined.
I sense, too, in a way that the new recruitment of the new institutions, the swelling of the system, really now defines it much more clearly than had been the case in the past.
I think that and the symbolism of moving the system off this campus.
I still remember Tom Harrington telling me,
70s at least, that the greatest mistake A&M made was not keeping Arlington and not moving the systems offices to Dallas.
And I thought, Tom Harrington said that?
This Aggie?
Absolutely.
And I think that will yet happen, not necessarily at Dallas.
But I think at some point in the evolution, the system offices should be probably in Austin, I do think, or in Houston now.
The center of gravity has shifted there.

and that would be good for this campus and I think would make it easier for those that have to deal with the chancellor staff that has to be out and around the whole state or people coming in to visit the system would make it easier but that's somewhere down the road but I think physically having them off the size of the chancellor and I think there was a third important move and it was creation of the super dean deputy chancellor I'm not
convinced that's the final form of that.
But that was a lot better than the one where you had the agency head reporting to the chancellor, the dean reporting to the provost president, and faculty got in the middle.
That was really bad.
And then, you know, you had this joint appointment, and the agencies generally won those battles because they had the resources.
The dean's over here trying to run a promotion tenure process without resources.
And that led to some really, really unfortunate, I think, or bad things.
Putting the dean agency head in one hat, as we have now in Hyler and Petticoat and Herzog, brings that matrix together.
Now the communication has to be between those people and the provost.
president, because the provost can get left out of the loop.
Those people with their dual hack can go right to the chancellor.
But again, I think it's working because we have good people being engaged, well-regarded, Eilers, Petticord, and Herb before him.
So that'll work.
Ideally, I think the agencies ought to be under the president.
And that may or may not happen.
There are reasons, important reasons, for keeping the agencies separate.
They have separate agency status in the state budget and the state mentality, and that's very important for budget things.
They're not in there competing with other sources.
Second, they are allowed to keep their own indirect costs, unlike the university and research.
Very important, significant.
So we want to keep the identity.

But the cleanest way, I think, would either be to make the president or the provost, either one, because they really report to the provost in their dean role, to make the president or provost a vice chancellor of the system, for example, where those people would report to that person in a system role and would accomplish the same thing.
That would integrate it.
That would integrate it.
It is also true the agencies have statewide, and they're trying to help the other schools.
So that's fine.
But the reality is the bulk of the work is done by faculty on this campus who have two bosses.
And that has to come together.
It's working now.
I don't think it's much better than I think it's probably ever been.
I think it is.
So there's no need to be precipitous.
But I think some place down the road,

put them under the university and try to protect their independent status, or take the president or provost and give them also a system hat that makes the ag and engineering agencies also report through that hat.
And it wouldn't even take an office over there, it's just a paper reporting thing.
which would make sure the provost, in particular, is in the middle of any academic thing that involves faculty here.
But overall, I think it's very important.
And the chancellor's role, I think, is essential in representing the whole system to the state and in championing the smaller schools.
and then dealing with the board.
As the growth of the system itself, how does that affect Texas A&M University, the main campus?
Do you see it as being competitive or complementary?
In theory it should be complementary, and in some ways we're seeing some of those advantages.
Clearly there are opportunities for joint programs.
Corpus Christi sitting down there on the ocean ought to be complementary with our Galveston oceanography programs here and atmospheric and the Gulf of Mexico kind of interest.
Agriculture at ANI is very strong.
They've got gas engineering down there.
There are a couple interfaces.
And that's true.
I think if you looked at a matrix there, there are overlaps where there ought to be some synergy both ways.
The cost of shared services, computer resources, library resources, as this electronic era advances,
Those smaller schools are going to benefit from access here, but we're also going to benefit.
I understand Corpus Christi has a superb collection of Texas, Texana kinds of things, and maps of old Texas and Mexico.
Well, that will be of interest to people here.
So our ability to share and access resources is a plus.
Third, as the state becomes more diverse, and as it indeed is, the reality is there will be no racial ethnic majority in Texas probably around 2020.
That's already the case in our urban areas.
Texas A&M has to become more diverse.
And if we don't, we're not going to have any political support.
because the state leadership is already happening in the legislature.
The legislature is more diverse, and they want to see that we're helping educate.
So that's not to say a social statement.
That's a political and economic reality.
Well, these other schools can be feeders for us, that Laredo and A&I, high percentage Hispanic, Pan American, Prairie View,
high percentage African American, if we can recruit some of their best and brightest into our graduate program, that should be a natural.
That hadn't really occurred in significant ways yet, but it ought to as we get.
Do you see the growth of Texas A&M assuming more and more the graduate role and being in effect a
The mothership for these?
Well, in part, but the other schools aspired to develop some graduate programming themselves, and they don't want, I think, us just to skim their best students.
But I think the reality is this is a national, international university of some distinction getting better all the time, and good, strong academic students are going to want to
the best in terms of peers and faculty and labs.
So I think we will.
But I don't think, I don't see our undergraduate mission diminishing.
The goal has been for a number of years, and it preceded me, really I guess the Target 2000 thing that George Mitchell chaired, was to get to 25% graduate
And we're a little over 20%, I think, now.
So it's been slow, but we're probably on track for that.
But I wouldn't see it going much beyond that.
I think we'll still have a very large undergraduate program and a good mix.
But I think this will be a place where
students that have some academic strengths as well as leadership potential are probably going to migrate.
How did you come to be president of Texas A&M?
Well, there was a search committee, and I guess they recommended me, and I think at that time, I think Perry Atkinson, I think the chancellor was supportive, and that always helps, and
Apparently enough of the regents were supportive.
Were they looking for anything special?
I don't know.
My sense was, you know, if you looked around the country at that time, several presidents were named that had more of a business orientation or came out of business schools.
And I think that probably was not
By chance.
I don't know if there was any conscious notion.
But I think clearly the resource constraints were getting much more serious and tighter.
And it was clear to all that we were going to have to do more in the efficiency kinds of things.
Second, I think it was evident that public institutions like private were going to have to
and have to take on more private fundraising.
I happen to enjoy that part of the role.
Some don't.
So I think that, to the extent one enjoys the fundraising and the external role.
Third, the legislative interface is clearly going to become more important and always important, but I think it is resources.

we're getting tighter that be someone that liked you know wander around the halls or go visit legislators and then kind of dig into that that battle and then I think probably just someone who who appreciated the uniqueness of A&M and wanted to nurture its best but not you know not obviously not be resistant to change because change is gonna be inevitable but but but that
appreciate that this is a special place, a unique place, and there are a lot of the dimensions, that uniqueness, that deserve preserving.
So I guess those would be some of the variables, I would think, that might have played into the decision process.
What was your biggest challenge as you walked into the president's office?
I think probably the resource issue.
We were coming off such a high in Texas in the early 80s, and oil prices soaring and expectations so high.
And this university has come so far and so quickly in terms of size and quality and impact.
And I think just our expectations were so high and justifiable to kind of bring that

to some kind of focus and more realistic level, that state support was not going to be what it had been, that the permanent fund was not going to be the source, and yet not destroy enthusiasm or momentum or optimism.
So I think it was pretty clear by 88 that the resource issues were significant.
The athletic situation was tenuous the day I took over.
The day after I assumed office, I went to a meeting with the NCAA.
That's been prevalent throughout Aggie history.
Indeed.
But I am so confident we have made such progress in that area.
And we, as you know, have another situation going on right now.
But I am firmly convinced that it is an isolated incident and not systemic.
And then I'm extremely disappointed and frustrated and angry and all those things that we have another one.
But I think the reality is that we really
I know we have turned the corner that we are not far from being a model program.
And that's going to show in the next couple of years.
I'm just highly confident.
But that makes it all the more frustrating that we have another incident now because it just distracts from time, from image, from what we're really about.
And I think our coaches have demonstrated
they can be highly competitive and can do an effective job without breaking any rules.
So we don't need anybody out there, whether they're students or former students or anybody else, helping in ways that aren't needed.
I understand, but I committed in 1988 to get my arms around it, and I thought we were almost there, but we're not there yet.
Third, as kind of a personal issue, I wanted to also work with the faculty and others to further the international agenda of the university.
By tradition, A&M was and is an international university, I think, through our land grant status.
through just faculty interest in a lot of areas.
So already, we were the head of many universities.
But today, you can't go to a meeting.
As you know, in higher education, people are talking about, how are we going to internationalize the curriculum?
How are we going to get more students attuned to this global competition?
Well, A&M is far down the road, far down the road.
If we don't shoot ourselves in the foot, I think that all is going to take hold over the rest of this decade.
We need to get a lot more of our students access to a study abroad, I believe.
I think that's one of the most meaningful things.
And I'm hopeful during this capital campaign, we'll get some significant infusion of endowment dollars to support students to take at least a summer
where they can get an international experience.
So you see this as one of the major future thrusts or directions that Texas A&M is going to take?
Yes, because I think education, like business, by definition, is going to be global.
I think where the knowledge is being generated or the nature of the significant issues being dealt with, all just transcends national boundaries.
information network is right at the threshold.
And we're all bitnetting now with colleagues around the world on our computers.
And we'll be moving manuscripts and massive amounts of data around the world just so easily.
And interactive TV is just around the corner that we'll be interacting live with colleagues in Japan or South America.
So I think the whole nature of the way we communicate, the way we learn, the way we disperse knowledge is going to change.
And it's going to be global.
And indeed, our graduates are all going to be dealing, even though they may never work out of the country, they're going to be dealing with global economy, global transactions, global issues.
And we need to further that.
And I think we are.
And one of the greatest disabilities
liabilities in making that happen?
Well, I think a couple.
Just general resistance to change.
Using old paradigms or old models or old stereotypes.
When we started our campus in Japan, a lot of flack, reliving World War II.
And that's understandable for families that had
family members who fought in the Pacific or Japan.
That's 50 years ago.
That's a new world.
And Japan is either going to be one of our major allies and trading partners, or it's going to be the dominant economic force in the world.
Either way, we need to...
I spent a few weeks over there.
It was an incredible place.

I was in the Navy, I guess, in the 50s or something, and some Japanese officers came into our VOQ mess and sat down across the table, and one naval officer crawled across the table trying to get to that guy.
So I know what you mean when you talk about the old models.
Well, I think that's what, too, is resources.
I think individually for a student or family to say, I want to spend a summer or a semester abroad, there's a marginal cost to that, or it may preclude them from working.
So making it feasible, and then certainly programmatically for a faculty or department to have a major role abroad, it's been pretty good.
So getting the resource base in place to help that occur.
There are some bureaucratic things as well.
The state of Texas a couple of years ago
had policies in place which discouraged faculty to be, I mean, to get your foreign travel approved and go away to the governor.
Gee, Christmas for a state that, I mean, we are an international state already.
What are we, the 11th largest economy in the world if we were a republic?
In and of itself, yeah.
Major ports and major international companies and just
So we are a global state, but we don't always recognize it.
But it's coming, and I think we've got a role to educate the state and our legislature and others about what we are and what we can be as a state.
What do you think A&M's great strengths are in this development?
In the international?
Yeah.
Well, one, our graduates.
Or that will not only carry us into the international, but just into the future.
Into the future?
Yeah.
Well, that's the same answer.
That would be, I think, our graduates.
I think we are producing a good graduate that the external markets recognize.
And those external markets are employers, they're graduate schools, they're professional schools.
And I think our students are great.
